column9: Research science (e.g. genetics, climate science), Government
column21: 1) Documentation (and to a lesser extent software) is catered too much to creators of Frictionless Data. I think there is a need to provide documentation to *users* of Frictionless Data that answers the question: "I stumbled on this Frictionless Dataset. What is that? How can I read it into something I'm familiar with (dataframe, database)?"2) Although I appreciate the efforts towards a Frictionless Framework, I think the scope is too wide and as a result spread too thin. In my opinion, Frictionless Data is a means, not an end. Frictionless software should reflect that: it should provide fast functions to read, validate and create Frictionless data and then get out of the way. I would for example keep transformation functions out of scope, as these are better served by other frameworks (Pandas, dplyr, SQL).Note: I think the Frictionless Standards are excellent (and well documented).
column24: Allowing schema_sync for Table Schema at a specification level. That would allow one to validate dataset against community-approved Table Schemas, which would be a huge boon to interoperability.
column33: Frictionless is the only professional community I know that uses Discord. I would have preferred Slack.
column39: Even though the Frictionless Standards have been around for a couple of years now, I was surprised to discover how small the Frictionless Community feels (at least that is my impression via Discord). I wonder if that impression reflects reality and if so, how the community could collaborate with bigger partners (from e.g. the scientific community) to truly adopt Frictionless Standards in a substantial way.
